Alternate Fuel: 550 kg
Holding fuel flow: 2 250 kg/h
Extra Fuel: 0 kg
Discretionary Fuel: 0 kg

key_points: IMPORTANT NOTE: The modifications resulting from the updated fuel policy regulations, which came into effect on October 30, 2022, are only changes in wording but nothing really new
The terminology "extra fuel" has been replaced with "discretionary fuel
" EASA has clarified that the calculations and procedures pertaining to fuel calculations will remain unchanged, and there will be no new questions regarding the new "extra fuel" concept
learning.explanation: IMPORTANT NOTE: The modifications resulting from the updated fuel policy regulations, which came into effect on October 30, 2022, are only changes in wording but nothing really new. The terminology "extra fuel" has been replaced with "discretionary fuel." EASA has clarified that the calculations and procedures pertaining to fuel calculations will remain unchanged, and there will be no new questions regarding the new "extra fuel" concept. extra fuel, include anticipated delays or specific operational constraints that can be predicted discretionary fuel, include a quantity at the sole discretion of the commander For reference, additional information can be found in EASA's AIR OPS documentation. The total amount of fuel required for this commetcial flight should include the following fuel quantities: Taxi fuel + Trip fuel + Contingency fuel + Alternate Fuel + Final reserve fuel. Therefore, we have: Taxi Fuel: The Taxi fuel includes the fuel expected to be used prior to take-off and the fuel consumed by the use of the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU). In this question, the APU usage at the parking position is 0 minutes. For the calculation of the taxi fuel, we take into consideration the fuel consumption only at the departure aerodrome. Fuel flow during taxi: 11 kg per minute Planned taxi time: 10 minutes Taxi fuel = 11 kg/min x 10 min = 110 kg Trip Fuel: Average fuel flow is 2618 kg/h. We must calculate the flight time. We have TAS = 421 kt and average wind component = - 24 kt (headwind) ⇒ Ground Speed = TAS - Headwind component = 421 kt - 24 kt = 397 kt. With a Ground Speed of 397 kt (397 kt = 397 NM/h), the time required to cover the distance of 748 NM is: Time = Distance/Ground Speed = 748/397 Given that the flight time is 748/397 h and the average fuel flow is 2638 kg/h, the Trip fuel is: Trip fuel = (748/397) h x 2618 kg/h = 4 932.65 kg (approx. 4 933 kg) Contingency fuel: Question states that Contingency fuel is 5% of the Trip fuel. Since the Trip fuel is 4 933 kg, the Contingency fuel is: Contingency fuel = 0.05 x 4 933 kg = 246.65 kg (approx. 247 kg) Alternate fuel: Question states that Alternate fuel equals 550 kg. Final Reserve fuel: According to EASA Air Ops (AMC1 CAT. OP. MPA.150(b) Fuel Policy), the Final reserve fuel for an aeroplane with turbine engines, is the fuel to fly for 30 minutes at holding speed at 1500 ft above aerodrome elevation in standard conditions. From the question, the holding fuel flow is 2 250 kg/h. As a result, the Final reserve fuel is: Final reserve fuel = (30 x 2 250)/60 kg = 1 125 kg The total amount of fuel required for this commercial flight is: Total fuel = 110 kg + 4 933 kg + 247 kg + 550 kg + 1 125 kg = 6 965 kg.

content.question: During the pre-flight planning procedure of a Commercial Air Transport flight, the pilot reviews the serviceability of the GNSS via NOTAMs. What is the optimum decision, if, according to a NOTAM, fluctuations of the signal reception will take place during the RNP approach at the destination aerodrome at the time of arrival?

options.A: Carry on with the flight as there are two GPS receivers on board, which can compensate for signal fluctuation.
options.B: Prepare another approach based on radio navigation aids, as a back-up in case the GNSS signal is lost in flight.
options.C: Postpone the flight because the lack of GNSS achievability is very dangerous.
options.D: Cancel the flight and reschedule it when the GNSS signal reception is fully functioning as an RNP approach must be flown.

key_points: RNP approach procedure is a type of RNAV approach using GNSS and is generally charted under the title of RNAV (GNSS) or RNAV (GPS) and includes LNAV, LNAV/VNAV, LP and LPV
It is important before flight to check that there will be enough satellites visible for an accurate position at all stages of the flight, but especially for the destination and alternate airfield
The GNSS achievability can be verified by checking NOTAMs and the Notice Advisory to Navstar Users (NANU) messages
learning.explanation: RNP approach procedure is a type of RNAV approach using GNSS and is generally charted under the title of RNAV (GNSS) or RNAV (GPS) and includes LNAV, LNAV/VNAV, LP and LPV. It is important before flight to check that there will be enough satellites visible for an accurate position at all stages of the flight, but especially for the destination and alternate airfield. The GNSS achievability can be verified by checking NOTAMs and the Notice Advisory to Navstar Users (NANU) messages. An RNP cannot be flown with an unreliable signal. So, another approach must be planned using ground based radio navigation aids. Thus, the best decision is to prepare another approach based on radio navigation aids, as a back-up in case the GNSS signal is lost in flight.

Given the following information, what is the time to reach at the Point of Safe Return (PSR)?
Departure Time: 14:00
Wind: 270º/30 kt
Flight Track: 270º
TAS: 100 kt
Safe Endurance: 3 h

key_points: The Point of Safe Return (PSR) is the last point on a route at which it is possible to return to the departure airfield, arriving back with the required fuel reserves still available in the fuel tanks
The time an aircraft takes to reach at PSR is given by the formula: Time taken to PSR = (E x H) / (O + H), where: E = Safe Endurance based on the available fuel, H = GS Home and O = GS Out

For this question, the wind direction is exactly opposite to the track, thus the Groundspeed Out (O) is: O = TAS - Wind component = 100 kt - 30 kt = 70 kt and the Groundspeed Home (H): H = TAS + Wind component = 100 kt + 30 kt = 130 kt
learning.explanation: The Point of Safe Return (PSR) is the last point on a route at which it is possible to return to the departure airfield, arriving back with the required fuel reserves still available in the fuel tanks. The time an aircraft takes to reach at PSR is given by the formula: Time taken to PSR = (E x H) / (O + H), where: E = Safe Endurance based on the available fuel, H = GS Home and O = GS Out. For this question, the wind direction is exactly opposite to the track, thus the Groundspeed Out (O) is: O = TAS - Wind component = 100 kt - 30 kt = 70 kt and the Groundspeed Home (H): H = TAS + Wind component = 100 kt + 30 kt = 130 kt. So, substituting all the known values, we get: Time taken to PSR = (E x H) / (O + H) = (3 hr x 130 kt) / (70 kt + 130 kt) = 1.95 hr or 1 hr 57 min. Therefore, the aircraft will reach overhead PSR at: 14:00 + 01:57 = 15:57.

learning.explanation: Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) refers to a constellation of satellites providing signals from space that transmit positioning and timing data to GNSS receivers. The receivers then use this data to determine location. It is important before flight to check that there will be enough satellites visible for an accurate position at all stages of the flight, and that planned outages, maintenance or orbital corrections are not expected at the time of flight. This GNSS achievability can be verified by checking NOTAMs and the Notice Advisory to Navstar Users (NANU) messages, which provide updates on the GPS constellation. As NOTAMs are the only option here (NANUs are not an option), then that is the correct answer. Also, GNSS can be augmented by GBAS and SBAS and NOTAMs must be checked to ensure that those services are available for the time of usage. Augmentation such as GBAS, SBAS and RAIM check for errors and correct them and/or notify the flight deck of integrity faults. RAIM can be checked in advance of making a flight or particular GNSS based procedure, using some onboard avionics systems, or on the ground beforehand using the AUGUR RAIM prediction tool.

learning.explanation: The answer is VDF and not ATC clearance even though the frequency falls in the VHF Communication range, the NOTAM would mention an alternate frequency if the voice channel transmitter was not available. VHF Direction Finding VDF VDF provides a means of determining the aircraft bearing from a ground station. VDF stations are capable of measuring the direction of arrival of radio transmissions from aircraft. In earlier days, such a service operated in MF, HF, and VHF bands. Today, the service (for civil aviation) operates on frequencies from 118 to 137 MHz in the VHF band. These frequencies are identical with the working frequencies of the aircraft communication radio. If the communications transmitter on an aircraft is tuned to the VDF frequency and the transmitter is activated, the aerials at the VDF unit will detect the incoming transmission and each aerial element will feed a signal to the VDF receiver. Since the aerial elements will all be at slightly different distances from the source of the signal, each will detect a slightly different phase of that signal at the same instant. On some VDF units a simple digital read out gives the bearing. A ground DF station can give true or magnetic bearings. It is common to use the so-called «Q-codes»: QTE True bearing from the station QDR Magnetic bearing from the station QDM Magnetic bearing to the station QTF Position of a station taken by bearings from D/F stations QUJ True bearing to the station In practice, only QDM and QDR are normally used. The accuracy of the bearing is measured in degrees. Bearings are categorised, in accordance with the ICAO defined classifications, as given in the following list: Class A accurate within ± 2° Class B accurate within ± 5° Class C accurate within ± l0° Class D accuracy less than Class C Due to topography, some VDF stations are approved for use within certain sectors only. In that case, specific information for that aerodrome will be given in AIP. Stations that are listed in the AIP provide a ‘homing’ service. Generally the class of bearing is no worse than class B. (Many states will not permit Class C & D bearings to be provided). Ground DF stations should not be used as en-route navigation aids. Source: nordian.net

content.question:
Given the following information, at what time will the PET be reached?
Leg distance: 1000 NM
Leg track: 090°
TAS: 200 kt
Wind: 090°/20 kt
Departure time: 12:00

key_points: Solving from Heading (HDG) & Ground Speed (GS), knowing WV, TAS and required track
Set wind direction to 090º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top
learning.explanation: Solving from Heading (HDG) & Ground Speed (GS), knowing WV, TAS and required track. 1. Set wind direction to 090º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top. 2. Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 200 kt. 3. Mark the wind velocity 20 kt down from the centre point. 4. Initially, set the True Track under the "TRUE HEADING" index. GS home: 270º 5. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 220 kt. GS out: 090º 5. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 180 kt. We can now apply the formulas: Distance to PET = (GS home x Distance) / (GS out + GS home) Distance to PET = (220 x 1000) / (180 + 220) Distance to PET = 550 NM Time to PET = Distance to PET / GS out Time to PET = 550 / 180 = 3 h 3 min PET will be reached at: Departure time + Time to PET = 12 h + 3 h 3 = 15 h 3

content.question: Where can you, as a pilot, find information about the GNSS, which is not available at the destination airfield?

key_points: Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) refers to a constellation of satellites providing signals from space that transmit positioning and timing data to GNSS receivers

learning.explanation: Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) refers to a constellation of satellites providing signals from space that transmit positioning and timing data to GNSS receivers. The receivers then use this data to determine location. It is important before flight to check that there will be enough satellites visible for an accurate position at all stages of the flight. This GNSS achievability can be verified by checking NOTAMs and the Notice Advisory to Navstar Users (NANU) messages, which provide updates on the GPS constellation. Also, GNSS can be augmented by GBAS and SBAS and NOTAMs must be checked to ensure they are available for the time of usage. Furthermore, GNSS NOTAM provide information on individual satellite outages or temporary unavailability of service due to testing or anomalies and service outages at specific airports/airspaces. Therefore, the availability of the relevant satellites and any potential outages must be checked before flight.

W/V: 280/15

What is the distance of the PSR from the departure point?

key_points: The Point of Safe Return (PSR) is the last point on a route at which it is possible to return to the departure airfield arriving back with the required fuel reserves still available in the tanks
If the pilot chooses to continue past the PSR, he is now committed to landing at your destination

Time (to PSR) = E x H / 0 + H Where, E = Safe endurance based on available fuel; H = Ground speed home; 0 = Ground speed out Solving from Heading (HDG) & Ground Speed (GS), knowing WV, TAS and required track
learning.explanation: The Point of Safe Return (PSR) is the last point on a route at which it is possible to return to the departure airfield arriving back with the required fuel reserves still available in the tanks. If the pilot chooses to continue past the PSR, he is now committed to landing at your destination. Time (to PSR) = E x H / 0 + H Where, E = Safe endurance based on available fuel; H = Ground speed home; 0 = Ground speed out Solving from Heading (HDG) & Ground Speed (GS), knowing WV, TAS and required track. 1. Set wind direction to 280º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top. 2. Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 120 kt. 3. Mark the wind velocity 15 kt down from the centre point. 4. Initially, set the True Track under the "TRUE HEADING" index. GS home: 070º 5. Note that this heading would result in 3ºR drift and a track of 073º. 6. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading plus the drift gives a track of 070º. This occurs at a heading of 067º with 4ºR drift. 7. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 133 kt. GS out: 250º 5. Note that this heading would result in 4ºL drift and a track of 246º. 6. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading minus the drift gives a track of 250º. This occurs at a heading of 254º with 4ºL drift. 7. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 107 kt. We can now apply the formulas: Time (to PSR) = E x H / 0 + H Time to PSR = 2.4 x 133 / 107 + 133 = 1.33 h To find the distance from the departure airport to the PSR, we simply multiply the time to PSR by the GS OUT: 1.33 hrs × 107 kts = 142 NM.

learning.explanation: The Point of Safe Return (PSR) is the last point on a route at which it is possible to return to the departure airfield arriving back with the required fuel reserves still available in the tanks. If the pilot chooses to continue past the PSR, he is now committed to landing at your destination. Time (to PSR) = E x H / 0 + H Where, E = Safe endurance based on available fuel; H = Ground speed home; 0 = Ground speed out Solving from Heading (HDG) & Ground Speed (GS), knowing WV, TAS and required track. 1. Set wind direction to 250º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top. 2. Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 105 kt. 3. Mark the wind velocity 20 kt down from the centre point. 4. Initially, set the True Track under the "TRUE HEADING" index. GS home: 215º 5. Note that this heading would result in 9ºL drift and a track of 206º. 6. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading minus the drift gives a track of 215º. This occurs at a heading of 224º with 6ºL drift. 7. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 88 kt. GS out: 035º 5. Note that this heading would result in 6ºR drift and a track of 041º. 6. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading plus the drift gives a track of 035º. This occurs at a heading of 029º with 6ºR drift. 7. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 121 kt. We can now apply the formulas: Time (to PSR) = E x H / 0 + H Time to PSR = 2.5 x 88 / 88 + 121 = 1.053 h To find the distance from the departure airport to the PSR, we simply multiply the time to PSR by the GS OUT: 1.053 h × 121 kt ≈ 127 NM.

content.question: What is the difference between GNSS planned and unplanned outages?

options.D: Planned outages are notified in advance.

key_points: Notice Advisory to Navstar Users (NANU) is an advisory message to inform users of a change in the GPS constellation
These messages are released 72 hours in advance of planned maintenance
These messages are also used to notify users of unscheduled outages
learning.explanation: Notice Advisory to Navstar Users (NANU) is an advisory message to inform users of a change in the GPS constellation. These messages are released 72 hours in advance of planned maintenance. These messages are also used to notify users of unscheduled outages. General NANUs can be used to disseminate general GPS information. Outages come in two varieties: planned and unplanned. Planned are all the activities/events that have been scheduled and that could potentially have an impact on the Signal-in-Space (SiS) and/or the performance levels. Planned NAGUs aim to inform users about the activity/event with a reasonable advance notice, ahead of their occurrence. The planned outages, in space or ground segment, can potentially cause an outage of the broadcast satellite SiS. A planned outage will be announced ahead of time and usually means some sort of maintenance is taking place. Unplanned are all the activities/events that have an impact on the SiS and/or the performance levels that have not been scheduled and could not be foreseen in advance, before their occurrence. The aim of unplanned NAGUs is to inform users about the activity/event within a reasonable time, after their occurrence. The difference between the planned and unplanned outages of GPS is that a planned outage is well recognisable during flight preparation, because relevant monitoring tools and NOTAMs will most probably indicate some problems. On the other hand, in case of unplanned outage, it is possible that the pilot will become aware mid-flight that integrity is lost. Therefore, the pilot should develop and maintain good practise in using backup conventional navigation whenever possible.

learning.explanation: Before flight it is important to check that you will have coverage from enough satellites throughout all stages of your flight. To do this, you must ensure planned outages, maintenance or orbital corrections are not expected at the time of flight. This GNSS achievability can be verified by checking NOTAMs and the Notice Advisory to Navstar Users (NANU) messages, which provide updates on the GPS constellation. RAIM functions by monitoring the real-time satellite signal strength and integrity in order to ensure reliable GNSS position tracking. RAIM alone gives current conditions and does not warn of planned outages. For predictions, you could use the AUGUR RAIM prediction tool, which would inform you of when the satellite signals would be inadequate for an accurate position fix over a certain area, however these prediction tools mainly focus on satellite geometry and whether or not there are a sufficient number of satellites. Temporary degradations in signal strength/availability caused by GNSS interference testing for example, are usually only stated in NOTAMs. These NOTAMs specify the areas and times where signal degradation may occur due to non-satellite-related factors. Since these disruptions are external and temporary, they won't be shown in RAIM predictions, which mostly assess satellite performance.

key_points: Learning Objective 033
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 033.04.01.04.01: Define why it is important to check GNSS achievability. If it is intended to use GNSS during a flight, it is important to check beforehand that the system will be available. This includes checking the NOTAMs in particular, as they will advise of any issues such as jamming, satellite unserviceability, etc. which could make GNSS inaccurate or unusable. RAIM should also be checked before flights which require it. NOTAMs will NOT tell you if GNSS is available, it is always assumed to be available, but they may tell you it will be unavailable at a particular location, in which case, you must plan to use conventional navigational aids and procedures. If, for an IFR flight, there are no conventional procedures available, it means that the flight cannot be made to that airport. As we are given no further information, this is what we must assume.

content.question: An aircraft is scheduled to fly from Brussels (EBBR) to Malaga (LEMG) and the crew intend to use the GBAS Landing System (GLS) approach onto Runway 13 at LEMG. What is the appropriate source of information on the availability of GBAS augmentation at the estimated time of arrival?

options.C: The AUGUR GPS RAIM prediction tool

key_points: GBAS - GROUND BASED AUGMENTATION SYSTEM GBAS is a system that attempts to reduce the natural errors within the GNSS system by providing very localised augmentation to the satellite signals, via a VHF data broadcast (VDB) that a suitably equipped aircraft can receive and use to fix any position errors
It is also called "differential GPS", and can correct for errors induced by satellite clocks, ephemeris and ionospheric propagation to make the augmented GNSS signal very accurate
The GBAS can also, like its satellite based cousin, SBAS, give integrity warnings about faulty satellites, as it should be able to detect this at the nearby antennas
learning.explanation: GBAS - GROUND BASED AUGMENTATION SYSTEM GBAS is a system that attempts to reduce the natural errors within the GNSS system by providing very localised augmentation to the satellite signals, via a VHF data broadcast (VDB) that a suitably equipped aircraft can receive and use to fix any position errors. It is also called "differential GPS", and can correct for errors induced by satellite clocks, ephemeris and ionospheric propagation to make the augmented GNSS signal very accurate. The GBAS can also, like its satellite based cousin, SBAS, give integrity warnings about faulty satellites, as it should be able to detect this at the nearby antennas. GBAS is limited in the fact that it is very short range, spanning approximately 30km away from the relevant ground station (which is generally an airport). The operation of GBAS allows it to work in the same way as an ILS approach, down to 200ft minimums currently (but with the ability to carry out full auto-lands with appropriate legislation), and this is called the GBAS Landing System or GLS, and is a precision approach. It is tuned using a 5 digit channel number that picks up the correct VHF datalink signals for that approach. The availability of GBAS augmentation depends solely on the airport in question, in this case, Malaga. They are the ones who run the GBAS receivers, ground station and VDB transmitter, and therefore will mark any planned unserviceabilities as NOTAMs. It is quite tempting to choose the AUGUR RAIM prediction as the correct answer, and this might give the pilot an idea as to how many satelllites should be available for the GNSS system, but this is not what is being asked in the question.

Given the following information, at what time will the PSR be reached?
Safe Endurance: 6 hours
Leg track: 270°
TAS: 200 kt
Wind: 270°/20 kt
Departure time: 14:00

key_points: The Point of Safe Return (PSR) is the last point on a route at which it is possible to return to the departure airfield arriving back with the required fuel reserves still available in the tanks
If the pilot chooses to continue past the PSR, he is now committed to landing at your destination

Time (to PSR) = E x H / 0 + H Where, E = Safe endurance based on available fuel; H = Ground speed home; 0 = Ground speed out Solving from Heading (HDG) & Ground Speed (GS), knowing WV, TAS and required track
learning.explanation: The Point of Safe Return (PSR) is the last point on a route at which it is possible to return to the departure airfield arriving back with the required fuel reserves still available in the tanks. If the pilot chooses to continue past the PSR, he is now committed to landing at your destination. Time (to PSR) = E x H / 0 + H Where, E = Safe endurance based on available fuel; H = Ground speed home; 0 = Ground speed out Solving from Heading (HDG) & Ground Speed (GS), knowing WV, TAS and required track. 1. Set wind direction to 270º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top. 2. Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 200 kt. 3. Mark the wind velocity 20 kt down from the centre point. 4. Initially, set the True Track under the "TRUE HEADING" index. GS home: 090º 5. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 220 kt. GS out: 270º 5. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 180 kt. We can now apply the formulas: Time (to PSR) = E x H / 0 + H Time to PSR = 6 x 220 / 180 + 220 = 3 h 18 min PSR will be reached at: Departure time + Time to PSR = 14:00 + 3:18 = 17:18

If the TAS is 100 kt and the pilot must land with 30 minutes’ worth of fuel on board, what is the distance to the Point of Safe Return PSR, and how long will it take to get there

key_points: The Point of Safe Return (PSR) is the last point on a route at which it is possible to return to the departure airfield arriving back with the required fuel reserves still available in the tanks
If the pilot chooses to continue past the PSR, he is now committed to landing at your destination

learning.explanation: The Point of Safe Return (PSR) is the last point on a route at which it is possible to return to the departure airfield arriving back with the required fuel reserves still available in the tanks. If the pilot chooses to continue past the PSR, he is now committed to landing at your destination. Time (to PSR) = E x H / 0 + H Where, E = Safe endurance based on available fuel; H = Ground speed home; 0 = Ground speed out Solving from Heading (HDG) & Ground Speed (GS), knowing WV, TAS and required track. 1. Set wind direction to 270º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top. 2. Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 100 kt. 3. Mark the wind velocity 20 kt down from the centre point. 4. Initially, set the True Track under the "TRUE HEADING" index. GS home: 090º 5. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 120 kt. GS out: 270º 5. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 80 kt. We can now apply the formulas: Time (to PSR) = E x H / 0 + H Time to PSR = 3 x 120 / 80 + 120 = 1.8 h = 108 min To find the distance from the departure airport to the PSR, we simply multiply the time to PSR by the GS OUT: 1.8 h × 80 kt = 144 NM. Note: If the Pilot must land with 30 minutes of fuel remaining => our safe endurance will be total endurance - 30 min.

Determine the true altitude to make sure that the Minimum Obstacle Clearance Altitude (MOCA) is maintained. Given:

MOCA: 3 700 ft
Cruising level: FL050
OAT: ISA - 15ºC
QNH: 1 004 hPa
Aerodrome elevation: 1 500 ft

key_points: True Altitude = Indicated Altitude (standard pressure) + Pressure Correction + Temperature Correction (1) Pressure Correction: If QNH is higher than 1013 hPa => True Altitude is higher than Indicated Altitude
If QNH is lower than 1013 hPa => True Altitude is lower than Indicated Altitude

1013 – 1004 = 9 hPa 9 hPa x 30 ft = 270 ft With regards to this question, QNH is 9 hPa lower than standard, therefore, True altitude is 9 hPa lower than Indicated altitude => 5 000 ft - 270 ft = 4 730 ft
learning.explanation: True Altitude = Indicated Altitude (standard pressure) + Pressure Correction + Temperature Correction (1) Pressure Correction: If QNH is higher than 1013 hPa => True Altitude is higher than Indicated Altitude. If QNH is lower than 1013 hPa => True Altitude is lower than Indicated Altitude. 1013 – 1004 = 9 hPa 9 hPa x 30 ft = 270 ft With regards to this question, QNH is 9 hPa lower than standard, therefore, True altitude is 9 hPa lower than Indicated altitude => 5 000 ft - 270 ft = 4 730 ft. (2) Temperature Correction: Rule of Thumb: correction of 4% for each 10º deviation from ISA (1% for each 2.5ºC) If temperature is warmer than ISA => True Altitude is higher than IA. If temperature is colder than ISA => True Altitude is lower than IA. => Temperature Error Correction is only applied above QFE Datum (Aerodrome Level) – Column of air between the aircraft and the meteo station. The aircraft is 4 730 ft – 1 500 ft = 3 230 ft Above Aerodrome Level (AAL) For ISA -15ºC, correction equals 6%: 3 230 ft x 6% = 194 ft As ISA deviation is negative (-15ºC), True altitude is lower than Indicated altitude. Therefore, True Altitude = Indicated altitude(QNH) - Temperature error correction => 4 730 ft - 194 ft = 4 536 ft Learning Objective 033.04.02.02.02: Confirm true altitudes from given atmospheric data to ensure that statutory minimum clearance is attained.

content.question:
Given:
Distance from departure to destination: 500 NM
Safe Endurance: 4 h
TAS: 140 kt
Ground Speed Out: 150 kt
Ground Speed Home: 130 kt
What is the distance and time of the PSR from the departure point?

key_points: Time to PSR (Point of Safe Return): The Point of Safe Return (PSR) is the last point on a route at which it is possible to return to the departure airfield arriving back with the required fuel reserves still available in the tanks
Continuing passed the PSR you are now committed to landing at your destination
Time (to PSR) = E x H / (O + H) E = Safe Endurance based on available fuel H = Ground speed Home O = Ground speed Out PSR = 4 x 130 / (150 + 130) = 1
learning.explanation: Time to PSR (Point of Safe Return): The Point of Safe Return (PSR) is the last point on a route at which it is possible to return to the departure airfield arriving back with the required fuel reserves still available in the tanks. Continuing passed the PSR you are now committed to landing at your destination. Time (to PSR) = E x H / (O + H) E = Safe Endurance based on available fuel H = Ground speed Home O = Ground speed Out PSR = 4 x 130 / (150 + 130) = 1.85 hr = 1 hr 51 minutes = 111 minutes Distance = time x GS out = 1.85 x 150 = 278 NM

content.question:
Given:
CAS: 190 kt
Altitude: 9000 ft
Temperature: ISA -10° C
True Course TC: 350°
W/V: 320/40
Distance from departure to destination: 350 NM
Endurance: 3 hours
Actual time of departure: 11:05 UTC
The distance from departure to Point of Equal Time PET is:

key_points: (1) First, we must calculate TAS using the Flight Computer so we can then calculate GS: ISA temperature at 9 000 ft = 15 - 2 x 9 = -3º; if actual temperature = ISA - 10ºC, then actual temperature = -13ºC
On your flight computer, on the "AIRSPEED" window, align 9000 ft with -13ºC
On the Inner ring, look for CAS 190 kt and read the corresponding TAS value of approx
learning.explanation: (1) First, we must calculate TAS using the Flight Computer so we can then calculate GS: ISA temperature at 9 000 ft = 15 - 2 x 9 = -3º; if actual temperature = ISA - 10ºC, then actual temperature = -13ºC. On your flight computer, on the "AIRSPEED" window, align 9000 ft with -13ºC. On the Inner ring, look for CAS 190 kt and read the corresponding TAS value of approx. 214 kt. (2) Now, that we know our TAS - we can calculate our GS using TAS and Wind: Solving from Heading (HDG) & Ground Speed (GS), knowing WV, TAS and required track. 1. Set wind direction to 320º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top. 2. Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 214 kt. 3. Mark the wind velocity 40 kt down from the centre point. 4. Initially, set the True Track under the "TRUE HEADING" index. GS home: 170º 5. Note that this heading would result in 5ºL drift and a track of 165º. 6. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading minus the drift gives a track of 170º. This occurs at a heading of 175º with 5ºL drift. 7. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 248 kt. GS out: 350º 5. Note that this heading would result in 7ºR drift and a track of 357º. 6. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading plus the drift gives a track of 350º. This occurs at a heading of 343º with 5ºR drift. 7. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 178 kt. (3) We can now apply the formulas: Distance to PET = (GS home x Distance) / (GS out + GS home) Distance to PET = (248 x 350) / (178 + 248) Distance to PET = 203.8 NM Time to PET = Distance to PET / GS out

A pilot is planning a flight for 4th of December 2019 and checks the NOTAMs for his/her destination aerodrome Hamburg (EDDH). What is the relevance of the following NOTAM for the time from 1315Z to 1625Z?
Q)EDWW/QGAAU/I/NBO/A/000/999/5338N00959E030
A)EDDH
B)1912041315
C)1912041625
E)EGNOS IS NOT AVAILABLE FOR LPV

options.A: ABAS will NOT be available at Hamburg to use LPV minima.
options.B: ABAS will NOT be available to aircraft on any approaches to Hamburg.
options.C: SBAS will NOT be available at Hamburg to use LPV minima.
options.D: SBAS outage prevents 3D RNAV approaches to Hamburg.

key_points: Satellite Based Augmentation Systems (SBAS) provide a high level of accuracy over a wide area (in contrast to GBAS, which provides accuracy to a small area), using satellites to send correction data to the aircraft
There are four systems under operation, which work on the same basic principle
One of them is the European Geostationary Navigation Overlay System (EGNOS) in Western Europe and the Mediterranean
learning.explanation: Satellite Based Augmentation Systems (SBAS) provide a high level of accuracy over a wide area (in contrast to GBAS, which provides accuracy to a small area), using satellites to send correction data to the aircraft. There are four systems under operation, which work on the same basic principle. One of them is the European Geostationary Navigation Overlay System (EGNOS) in Western Europe and the Mediterranean. EGNOS uses three geostationary INMARSAT (International Maritime Satellite Organisation) satellites, which broadcast GPS signals, provide horizontal accuracy of around 0.7 m and vertically around 1.1 m and it, also, alerts users within 6 seconds if a GPS malfunction occurs. LPV is a 3D approach with vertical guidance (APV), like a conventional ILS, but using GNSS augmented by SBAS, with no barometric input. According to the NOTAM, the EGNOS system, which is an SBAS system, is not available for LPV approaches, thus for LPV minima.

learning.explanation: ITEM 19 - Endurance After E/ INSERT a 4-figure group giving the fuel endurance in hours and minutes. Fuel Endurance in Item 19 of ATC Flight Plan is for Search Radius, in case an Aircraft is reported missing or overdue. It must be the Total Fuel Endurance of the Aircraft, and must take into account the Total Fuel On-Board - it is the time the aircraft can remain airborne, and, therefore, includes all usable fuel onboard (including any reserves). learning.explanation: ICAO Doc 4444 16.4 - USE OF REPETITIVE FLIGHT PLANS (RPLS) 16.4.1 General 16.4.1.1 - RPLs shall not be used for flights other than IFR flights operated regularly on the same day(s) of consecutive weeks and on at least ten occasions or every day over a period of at least ten consecutive days. The elements of each flight plan shall have a high degree of stability. Note: For permissible incidental changes to RPL data affecting the operation for one particular day, and not intended to be a modification of the listed RPL, see 16.4.4.2.2 and 16.4.4.2.3. 16.4.1.2 - RPLs shall cover the entire flight from the departure aerodrome to the destination aerodrome. Use the following information to determine what would be entered into ITEM 19 ENDURANCE of the ICAO Flight Plan form.
Flight rules: VFR
Environment: Non-hostile
Taxi Fuel: 20 kg
Trip distance: 412 NM
Average trip TAS: 140 kt
Average Trip Fuel flow: 430 kg/h
Average wind component: +15 kt
Time to alternate: 25 minutes
Final Reserve Fuel: 30 minutes holding T/O
Fuel: minimum required

key_points: After E/ INSERT a 4-figure group giving the fuel endurance in hours and minutes

learning.explanation: After E/ INSERT a 4-figure group giving the fuel endurance in hours and minutes. Note: the taxi fuel is not included in the endurance figure. Endurance by definition is the time the aircraft can remain airborne on the fuel contained in the tanks - therefore disregard the taxi fuel and time. It includes all of the usable fuel on board, including any reserves. Endurance = the time airborne before the tanks run dry. TAS=140 kt, if the average wind is +15, it means it is tailwind, so Ground speed => 140 + 15 = 155 kts Trip distance 412 NM = 155 * t (time) = 2.66 hours =>160 minutes We also need to find Contingency Fuel => if the trip time 2.66 hours and fuel flow per hour is 430 kg, we will burn (430 *2.66) = 1 144 kg, Contingency fuel 5% trip fuel =>1 144 * 0.05 = 57 kg If we burn 430 kg per hour, we can airborne 8 minutes with 57 kg contingency fuel. Trip: 160 minutes Contingency Fuel: 8 minutes Alternate: 25 minutes Final Reserve Fuel: 30 minutes Total =>223 minutes => 3 hour 43 minutes

Fuel Endurance in Item 19 of ATC Flight Plan is for Search Radius, in case an Aircraft is reported missing or overdue. It must be the Total Fuel Endurance of the Aircraft, and must take into account the Total Fuel On-Board - it is the time the aircraft can remain airborne, and, therefore, includes all usable fuel onboard (including any reserves). However, it does not include taxi fuel. Calculate the Fuel Flow: Fuel Flow = Trip Fuel / Flight Time Fuel Flow = 100 kg / 1h 35 min = 63.16 kg/h Calculate Total Fuel onboard at take off (excluding Taxi Fuel): Take-Off Fuel = Block Fuel - Taxi Fuel = 181 kg - 3 kg = 178 kg Calculate Endurance: Endurance = Take-Off Fuel / Fuel Flow = 178 kg : 63.16 kg/h = 2 h 49 min

content.question:
An aircraft is flying along a true course of 276º and the actual wind is different than the forecast wind. The forecast wind is 240/15 and the actual wind is 290/25. The airspeed remains the same. Which statements are correct or incorrect?
1) The lower ground speed will result in a later time of arrival.
2) The wind correction angle will change from a value to the right to a value to the left.

key_points: 1) "The lower ground speed will result in a later time of arrival

" Correct: With the actual wind coming from 290 degrees at 25 kt (instead of 240/15), while the aircraft is heading along a true course of 276º, it means that the aircraft is flying somewhat into a stronger headwind component (and weaker crosswind)
This stronger headwind component will reduce the ground speed
learning.explanation: 1) "The lower ground speed will result in a later time of arrival." Correct: With the actual wind coming from 290 degrees at 25 kt (instead of 240/15), while the aircraft is heading along a true course of 276º, it means that the aircraft is flying somewhat into a stronger headwind component (and weaker crosswind). This stronger headwind component will reduce the ground speed. A lower ground speed means it will take more time to cover the same distance, resulting in a later time of arrival. 2) "The wind correction angle will change from a value to the right to a value to the left." Incorrect: The change in wind direction and speed from the forecast (240/15) to the actual (290/25) wind means the wind correction angle will likely change. The wind correction angle is the angle by which the pilot adjusts the heading to compensate for the crosswind component of the wind. Under the forecasted wind, the wind is causing the aircraft to drift to the right, necessitating a wind correction angle to the left. In contrast, with the wind now arriving from the right of the aircraft, it will tend to push the aircraft to the left, thereby requiring a wind correction angle to the right.

content.question: The minimum climb gradient for obstacle clearance is 4%. TAS for the best rate of climb is 230 kt. Given a tailwind of 15 kt, what minimum rate of climb can be achieved?

key_points: Rate of climb is independent of wind, only climb angle (and flight path climb gradient) will be affected by a headwind or tailwind
It means you will reach a specific altitude in the same time interval, but your ground distance will be affected
HOWEVER, for obstacle clearance purposes, wind should be taken into consideration
learning.explanation: Rate of climb is independent of wind, only climb angle (and flight path climb gradient) will be affected by a headwind or tailwind. It means you will reach a specific altitude in the same time interval, but your ground distance will be affected. HOWEVER, for obstacle clearance purposes, wind should be taken into consideration. Therefore, we have: Rate of climb (ft/min) = Climb Gradient (%) x GS (kt) We can assume ROC remains constant even if we experience a tailwind of 15 kt. Rate of climb (ft/min) = Climb Gradient (%) x GS (kt) If we convert GS unit from kt to ft/min → 245 kt x 6 080 ft / 60 min = 24 827 ft/min Rate of climb (ft/min) = 4% x 24 827 ft/min = 993 ft/min

Given the following information, what is the Air distance (NAM) covered?
TAS: 120 kt
Headwind component: 20 kt
Ground Distance: 200 NGM

key_points: A relationship exists between air distance and ground distance, as well as between True airspeed and Ground speed, given by the following equation, which is equal to the Flight time: TIME = NAM / TAS = NGM / GS Solving for NAM and substituting the known values of the above equation, we get: NAM = NGM x TAS / GS = 200 NGM x 120 kt / (120 - 20) kt = 240 NAM
OR The flight time to cover 200 NGM is: Time = NGM / GS= 200 NM / (120 - 20) kt = 2 hr
So, the Air distance will be: NAM = TAS x Time = 120 kt x 2 hr = 240 NAM

content.question:
An aircraft is flying under VFR on a track of 168°M. The elevation of the highest obstacle within 5 NM of the intended track of the aircraft is 4200 ft. Given the following information, provided by an aerodrome at 1400 ft elevation, what is the minimum flight level which will give an obstacle clearance 1000 ft?
QNH: 1026 hPa
Temperature: 12°C below ISA
Assume 1 hPa = 30 ft

key_points: This is a typical "Altimetry Error question", which requires both pressure and temperature correction: The Minimum True Altitude to clear the obstacle is: 4200 ft + 1000 ft = 5200 ft
The ISA deviation is given: -12oC

After applying the temperature correction, the minimum true altitude will be: Min True Altitude - [4 x (True Altitude from Pressure Datum/1000) x ISA deviation] = 5200 ft - [4 x (5200 ft - 1400 ft)/1000) x (-12oC)] = 5200 ft + 182 ft = 5382 ft
learning.explanation: This is a typical "Altimetry Error question", which requires both pressure and temperature correction: The Minimum True Altitude to clear the obstacle is: 4200 ft + 1000 ft = 5200 ft. The ISA deviation is given: -12oC. After applying the temperature correction, the minimum true altitude will be: Min True Altitude - [4 x (True Altitude from Pressure Datum/1000) x ISA deviation] = 5200 ft - [4 x (5200 ft - 1400 ft)/1000) x (-12oC)] = 5200 ft + 182 ft = 5382 ft. After applying the pressure correction, the minimum pressure altitude will be: 5382 ft + [(1013 hPa - QNH) x 30 ft] = 5382 ft + [(1013 hPa - 1026 hPa) x 30 ft] = 5382 ft - (13 hPa x 30 ft) = 5382 ft - 390 ft = 4992 ft. According to the "ICAO VFR Semi-Circular Rule": For Easterly Magnetic tracks (000o - 179o), the Flight Levels are: Odd FLs + 500 ft (FL35, FL55, FL75, etc.). For Westerly Magnetic tracks (180o - 359o), the Flight Levels are: Even FLs + 500 ft (FL25, FL45, FL65, etc.). The aircraft flies an easterly magnetic track of 168o(M), thus the Minimum Flight Level, which provides obstacle clearance, after both pressure and temperature correction, that must be selected is: FL55.

You are planning a VFR flight from Schärding Süben (LOLS) (48°24'11"N, 013°26'53"E) to Pfarrkirchen (EDNP) (48°25'12"N, 012°51'53"E) aerodromes, which of the following statements are true?
1. The cruising altitude should be 5500 ft
2. Your route follows the river "Rott" Westwards

5. Your route follows the A3 motorway Northwards

key_points: Firstly, find the exact position of the two aerodromes, using the coordinates given and examine each statement carefully
The aircraft follows a Westerly magnetic track from Schärding Süben (LOLS) to Pfarrkirchen (EDNP) aerodromes
According to the ICAO VFR semi-circular rule, for a westerly magnetic track, Even FLs/Altitudes + 500 ft should be flown (2 500 ft, 4 500 ft, 6 500 ft, etc
learning.explanation: Firstly, find the exact position of the two aerodromes, using the coordinates given and examine each statement carefully. The aircraft follows a Westerly magnetic track from Schärding Süben (LOLS) to Pfarrkirchen (EDNP) aerodromes. According to the ICAO VFR semi-circular rule, for a westerly magnetic track, Even FLs/Altitudes + 500 ft should be flown (2 500 ft, 4 500 ft, 6 500 ft, etc.). So, a cruise altitude of 6 500 ft can be followed, which apart from being according to the ICAO rule, it provides obstacle clearance too. It is a bit higher than you might usually use for this route, but it is perfectly acceptable nonetheless. content.question: Along the route the highest obstacle is 13 421 feet AMSL. If the QNH is 989 hPa, the MT is 311° and the temperature is 10 degrees below ISA, the lowest appropriate VFR flight level that you could choose in order to clear this obstacle by a minimum of 2000 feet is:

key_points: You need to fly 2 000 ft above an obstacle, 13 421 ft AMSL
Therefore, you need to fly at a True Altitude of 15 421 ft AMSL

Knowing our True Altitude, let's find Indicated Altitude: Indicated Altitude = True Altitude + Temperature Correction + Pressure correction Temperature Correction Rule of thumb: correction of 4% for each 10ºC deviation from ISA ISA deviation = -10ºC
learning.explanation: You need to fly 2 000 ft above an obstacle, 13 421 ft AMSL. Therefore, you need to fly at a True Altitude of 15 421 ft AMSL. Knowing our True Altitude, let's find Indicated Altitude: Indicated Altitude = True Altitude + Temperature Correction + Pressure correction Temperature Correction Rule of thumb: correction of 4% for each 10ºC deviation from ISA ISA deviation = -10ºC. Therefore we will apply a correction of 4%. 15 421 ft x 4% = 617 ft As ISA deviation is negative (-10ºC), Indicated altitude is greater than True altitude. Indicated Altitude = 15 421 ft + 617 ft = 16 038 ft Pressure correction If the current QNH is 989 hPa, the difference to standard pressure will be: 1013 hPa – 989 hPa = 24 hPa Assuming a barometric lapse rate of 30ft/hPa: 24 hPa x 30 ft/hPa = 720 ft Since our current QNH is lower than standard, Indicated altitude is greater than True altitude: 16 038 ft + 720 ft = 16 758 ft. This altitude is also called Pressure altitude (PA). Remember that you are flying Westbound on a VFR flight - Therefore, your flight level should be EVEN and you should use the intermediate 500 ft => The Lowest usable flight level will be FL185 Further info on Cruising Levels: VFR and IFR aircraft are allocated different levels to fly at: IFR flights use whole 1000's of feet (e.g. 1000, 3000 etc. when flying eastbound, and 2000, 4000 etc. when flying westbound) VFR flights use the intermediate 500 ft. levels (e.g. 3500, 5500 etc. when flying eastbound and 4500, 6500 when flying westbound)

Refer to figure.
An aircraft is doing some aerial work while flying VFR in the vicinity of LOGI (N47°29.7' E014°29.9'). Which flight level is most suitable for the activity?
Temperature = ISA -15°C
QNH = 1018 hPa

key_points: Calculation of terrain clearance and flight level Upon inspection of LOGI, we can see that it is situated between 4 different areas with different Grid MORAs (Minimum Off-Route Altitude)
We must take the highest Grid MORA, in order to ensure that we have a safe vertical separation
The aircraft must fly at 10 800 ft
learning.explanation: Calculation of terrain clearance and flight level Upon inspection of LOGI, we can see that it is situated between 4 different areas with different Grid MORAs (Minimum Off-Route Altitude). We must take the highest Grid MORA, in order to ensure that we have a safe vertical separation. The aircraft must fly at 10 800 ft. This must be the true altitude of the aircraft. This altitude must be corrected for any temperature ISA deviation and then any difference in pressure from standard (1013 hPa), to get the pressure altitude, allowing us to work out the lowest usable flight level. The first step is to determine the temperature correction. The ISA deviation is ISA -15°C. Based on the 4% rule and its calculation mentioned in the rules below, the height correction for the temperature can be calculated as follows: Height correction for temperature = 4 × (-15) × (10 800/1000) = -648 ft. The temperature correction is added to the true altitude as per the rules below, to give an indicated altitude of 11 448 ft. Next, we need to compute the pressure correction by considering the deviation from the standard mean sea level pressure of 1013 hPa: 1018 hPa - 1013 hPa = 5 hPa. Since the barometric lapse rate near the surface is 30 ft/hPa, the pressure correction can be calculated as follows: Pressure correction = (5) x 30 ft/hPa = 150 ft. This value needs to be subtracted from the indicated altitude as per the rules below: Pressure Altitude = 11 448 - 150 = 11 298 ft Since we are a VFR flight, we are required to fly at altitudes that are whole thousands plus 500 feet. The only altitude above 11 298 ft which also obeys this rule is FL115. RULES. The following rules should be considered for altimetry calculations: All calculations are based on rounded pressure values to the nearest lower hPa. The value for the barometric lapse rate between MSL and 500 hPa to be used is 30 ft/hPa as an acceptable approximation of the barometric lapse rate. To determine the true altitude/height, the following rule of thumb, called the ‘4 %-rule’, shall be used: the altitude/height changes by 4% for each 10°C temperature deviation from ISA. For simplification: Height correction for the temp = 4 × (ISA DEV) × Indicated alt/1000 = _____ ft If no further information is given, the deviation of the outside-air temperature from ISA is considered to be the same throughout the whole layer. The elevation of the aerodrome has to be taken into account. The temperature correction has to be considered for the layer between the station (usually an aerodrome) and the position of the aircraft. HIGHER PRESSURE; INDICATED ALTITUDE > PRESSURE ALTITUDE LOWER PRESSURE; INDICATED ALTITUDE < PRESSURE ALTITUDE WARMER THAN ISA; TRUE ALTITUDE > INDICATED ALTITUDE COLDER THAN ISA; TRUE ALTITUDE < INDICATED ALTITUDE DEFINITIONS. Pressure Altitude: The altimeter indication with standard pressure (1013.2 hPa) set. Indicated Altitude: The altimeter indication with local QNH set. True altitude: The actual altitude of the aircraft above mean sea level.

content.question: How do you determine the position of a significant VFR waypoint for insertion into a Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) flight plan?

options.A: By typing in the name of a city, town, or village and the corresponding bearing and distance from it.
options.B: By using the distance and bearing from an existing significant point or using coordinates.
options.C: By using any designator of waypoints from IFR charts.
options.D: By inserting the coordinates of the airport reference point, then bearing and distance from it.

key_points: Although operating VFR, a significant VFR point (i
e

Fixpoint or VFR reporting point) can be inserted into a GNSS flight plan, even if it is not held in the database, by defining it as a distance and bearing from an existing significant point (Geographic point or VOR/DME) or by coordinates
learning.explanation: Although operating VFR, a significant VFR point (i.e. Fixpoint or VFR reporting point) can be inserted into a GNSS flight plan, even if it is not held in the database, by defining it as a distance and bearing from an existing significant point (Geographic point or VOR/DME) or by coordinates. A waypoint on a low altitude IFR chart is not relevant to a VFR point. A bearing and distance from a city, town or village is not accurate or practical and will not necessarily be in the flight plan.

content.question: Refer to Nantes chart 19-1 from Jeppesen GSPRM. An aeroplane is departing from Nantes to conduct VFR flight to the northwest and will cross waypoint (NW). What will be the best visual check point to check the position at waypoint (NW).

options.A: The lighted mast next to NW.
options.B: By checking your position using GNSS.
options.C: By checking your position with bearing and distance from NTS VOR/DME.
options.D: By looking for the highway junction, which is the only junction in that area.

key_points: During VFR flights you can best pinpoint your position using unique line features, such as railway lines, motorways or junctions of those
Small built-up areas are recommended, when they are isolated and close to obvious ground features, such as lakes, reservoirs, junctions and nearby to identify it
Choice of the ground features is critical, as things that show up well on maps do not necessarily show up well from the air
learning.explanation: During VFR flights you can best pinpoint your position using unique line features, such as railway lines, motorways or junctions of those. Small built-up areas are recommended, when they are isolated and close to obvious ground features, such as lakes, reservoirs, junctions and nearby to identify it. Choice of the ground features is critical, as things that show up well on maps do not necessarily show up well from the air. In the vicinity of Nantes aerodrome there are many identical ground features, such as lighted masts, which can cause confusion to the pilot's flight monitoring, since they cannot be considered as unique. In this case, the best option to check the position at waypoint "NW", is by looking for the highway junction, which is the only junction in that area and at a distance from the other motorway junctions, so as to ensure that the planned route is followed and to correct promptly any inattention which may cause any inadvertent drift.

content.question: An aircraft is climbing from 3000 ft to 8000 ft on a 3° path at an average GS of 210 kt. The altitude of 8000 ft will be reached in (1) _____ and the ground distance covered will be (2) _____.

key_points: For a climb with 3◦ path the rate of climb can be found by the formula: Rate of Climb (fpm) = 5 x Ground Speed (knots) = 5 x 210 = 1050 fpm 2
The time to climb from 3000 ft to 8000 ft is: Time to climb (min) = Height difference (ft) / ROC (fpm) = (8000 ft - 3000 ft) / 1050 fpm = 4
learning.explanation: 1. For a climb with 3◦ path the rate of climb can be found by the formula: Rate of Climb (fpm) = 5 x Ground Speed (knots) = 5 x 210 = 1050 fpm 2. The time to climb from 3000 ft to 8000 ft is: Time to climb (min) = Height difference (ft) / ROC (fpm) = (8000 ft - 3000 ft) / 1050 fpm = 4.76 min or 4 min and 46 sec. 3. The Ground distance covered during the climb is: Ground distance (NM) = GS (knots) x Time (hours) = 210 kt x 4.76/60 hr = 16.7 NM.

content.question:
A mountain 6 011 ft AMSL will be crossed. What is the lowest VFR ICAO level the aircraft must fly to obtain a clearance of 2 000 ft? Given:
Variation: 10ºW
Aircraft's Track: 356º T
Aircraft's HDG: 355º M
QNH: 990 hPa
Assume 1 hPa = 30 ft

key_points: First considerations: To obtain a terrain clearance of 2 000 ft, the aircraft must be flown at a true altitude of = 6 011 ft + 2 000 ft = 8 011 ft When flying Flight Levels, the altimeter is set to Standard Pressure (1013 hPa)
Pressure Correction: Note: If QNH is higher than 1013 hPa => True Altitude is higher than IA
If QNH is lower than 1013 hPa => True Altitude is lower than IA
learning.explanation: First considerations: To obtain a terrain clearance of 2 000 ft, the aircraft must be flown at a true altitude of = 6 011 ft + 2 000 ft = 8 011 ft When flying Flight Levels, the altimeter is set to Standard Pressure (1013 hPa). Pressure Correction: Note: If QNH is higher than 1013 hPa => True Altitude is higher than IA. If QNH is lower than 1013 hPa => True Altitude is lower than IA. Local pressure equals 990 hPa which is lower than standard pressure by 1013 hPa - 990 hPa = 23 hPa. 23 hPa x 30 ft/hPa = 690 ft Indicated Altitude = True Altitude + Pressure Correction Indicated Altitude = 8 011 ft + 690 ft = 8 701 ft Semicircular Flight Rules: IFR flight levels/altitudes are divisible by 1 000 ft (i.e. 7 000 ft, 8 000 ft, 9 000 ft). The VFR rules of flight level and/or altitude selection is the same as IFR ones with adding 500 ft to all levels. The default worldwide semi-circular rule is the East/West orientation of the flight level parity: Your aircraft has track between 0° and 179°, your flight level or altitude must be odd; Your aircraft has track between 180° and 359°, your flight level or altitude must be even. The appropriate altitude or flight level must be determined using the magnetic track (not heading). In this case, True Track (TT) equals 356º, applying the magnetic Variation provided (10ºW), we can find the Magnetic Track (MT) Variation West, magnetic direction BEST; Variation East, Magnetic Direction LEAST. MT = 356º + 10º = 006º According to the rules shared above, an ODD flight level + 500 ft must be used: First available Flight level above 8 701 ft => FL95

When reviewing the wind charts in the briefing room, you notice that the average wind in cruise will be 25 kt tailwind. Given following data, what will be the flight time to destination?
Time to top of climb: 30 min
Cruise leg: 740 NM
FL380
TAS: 460 kt
ISA: -10°C
Time to from top of descent to landing: 22 minutes

key_points: Let's begin by finding the cruise groundspeed: Cruise GS = TAS + tailwind = 460 kt + 25 kt = 485 kt Now, with the groundspeed determined, we can compute the cruising flight time: Time = (Distance ÷ GS) Time = 740 NM ÷ 485 kt = 1

55 minutes Finally, we can calculate the flight time to the destination: Flight time to destination = Time to top of climb + cruise + Time from top of descent to landing Flight time to destination = 30 minutes + 91
learning.explanation: Let's begin by finding the cruise groundspeed: Cruise GS = TAS + tailwind = 460 kt + 25 kt = 485 kt Now, with the groundspeed determined, we can compute the cruising flight time: Time = (Distance ÷ GS) Time = 740 NM ÷ 485 kt = 1.52577 hours = 91.55 minutes Finally, we can calculate the flight time to the destination: Flight time to destination = Time to top of climb + cruise + Time from top of descent to landing Flight time to destination = 30 minutes + 91.55 minutes + 22 minutes = 143.8 minutes Flight time to destination = 2 hours 24 minutes

content.question:
Refer to ED-4 VFR chart from Jeppesen GSPRM 2017. An aircraft on a VFR flight intends to fly overhead aerodrome Straubing (EDMS) (48°54' N, 012°31' E). Given the following information, what is the minimum indicated altitude required to clear the Straubing (EDMS) Class F airspace by 500 ft?
Altimeter temperature error with an OAT -7°C at Straubing (EDMS): 240 ft
QNH at Straubing (EDMS): 998 hPa
Altimeter setting: 998 hPa
(Round altitudes and elevations to the nearest 10 ft)

key_points: The upper vertical limit of the Straubing (EDMS) Class F airspace is 2 500 ft Above Ground Level (AGL) and the aerodrome's elevation is 1 054 ft
The altimeter temperature error correction is given, 240 ft, because of flying within a cold atmosphere with an OAT of -7°C
The correction must be added, because the indicated altitude will be higher than the true altitude in a cold atmosphere
learning.explanation: The upper vertical limit of the Straubing (EDMS) Class F airspace is 2 500 ft Above Ground Level (AGL) and the aerodrome's elevation is 1 054 ft. The altimeter temperature error correction is given, 240 ft, because of flying within a cold atmosphere with an OAT of -7°C. The correction must be added, because the indicated altitude will be higher than the true altitude in a cold atmosphere. The aircraft flies with an altimeter setting, 998 hPa, equal to the QNH of the Straubing aerodrome, thus no pressure correction is required. Therefore, the minimum indicated altitude to clear the Straubing (EDMS) Class F airspace by 500 ft is: 2 500 ft + 1 054 ft + 240 ft + 500 ft = 4 294 ft.

content.question: Which of the following statements is correct? The climb gradient is:

options.A: Always smaller than the angle of climb.
options.B: Always larger than the angle of climb.
options.D: The same as the angle of climb.

key_points: Climb gradient is the ratio between distance travelled over the ground and altitude gained and is expressed as a percentage
The angle of climb can be defined as the angle between a horizontal plane representing the Earth's surface and the actual flight path followed by the aircraft during its ascent
The climb gradient numerical value is always larger than the angle of climb
learning.explanation: Climb gradient is the ratio between distance travelled over the ground and altitude gained and is expressed as a percentage. The angle of climb can be defined as the angle between a horizontal plane representing the Earth's surface and the actual flight path followed by the aircraft during its ascent. The climb gradient numerical value is always larger than the angle of climb. For instance, 3º angle of climb equals approximately 5% gradient.

When flying a magnetic heading of 210°, the deviation is (1) _____ and the compass heading you'll have to fly is (2) _____.

key_points: The difference between the direction of magnetic north and that of compass north is called "deviation"
Deviation is measured in degrees and is described as "East" (+) or "West" (-)

content.question: Refer to VFR Chart ED-4 from the Jeppesen GSPRM 2017. A VFR flight is planned from Freiburg i. Br. airport (EDTF, N48°01.3’, E007°50.1’) to Offenburg airport (EDTO, N48°27.0’, E007°55.5’) at the lowest safe altitude. Which is the best visual reference landmark for drift and time deviation checks along the intended route?

options.A: The wind farm East off Altdorf-Wallburg (EDSW) airport.
options.C: The wind farm Southwest of Schweighausen town.
options.D: The unlighted tower North of Emmendingen town.

key_points: When planning a route, the pilot will use visual check points to monitor the flight progress along a flight leg
Choice of the ground features is critical, as things that show up well on maps, do not necessarily show up well from the air
Thus, the pilot, among others, should consider: Proximity to planned track: Ground features on or close to the track are preferred
learning.explanation: When planning a route, the pilot will use visual check points to monitor the flight progress along a flight leg. Choice of the ground features is critical, as things that show up well on maps, do not necessarily show up well from the air. Thus, the pilot, among others, should consider: Proximity to planned track: Ground features on or close to the track are preferred. Size and uniqueness: Large objects with colour contrast and/or some vertical extent will be easier to identify. Time of the year: Changes in vegetation or snow cover can cause the same landscape to take on a different appearance at different times of the year. Planned Altitude: At lower levels, a selected visual check point may be hidden by high ground or only visible after the aircraft has passed over it and for a limited period of time. Some of the problems faced by a pilot during VFR navigation at lower levels are the following: The horizon may be obscured by high ground, so attitude flying is difficult. Frequent changes may be needed to maintain the correct airspeed, while climbing or descending over undulating ground. The view ahead and around is restricted by the next fold of high ground. The angle at which you are looking becomes flatter and if a feature does not have some vertical extent (such as towers and wind farms), you are unlikely to see it at low level. A selected visual check point may be hidden by high ground or only visible after the aircraft has passed over it and for a limited period of time (such as a river). Thus, towers and wind farms are the most suitable ground features for low level VFR navigation. But, among them, the best ones are those which are along the route and as close to the departure airport as possible, because the pilot will be aware of any drift or time deviation at the initial stages of the cruise phase proceeding in minor recalculations. Therefore, the visual reference landmark which best covers the forementioned criteria is the unlighted tower North of the town of Emmendingen, with elevation of 1 384 ft. content.question:
You plan to fly over high terrain of 6 240 ft where a minimum clearance altitude of 2 000 ft is required. An airport nearby at an altitude of 1 240 ft reports a QNH of 1000 hPa and the OAT is ISA -12ºC. What is the lowest usable flight level?
(Assume: 1 hPa = 30 ft)

key_points: Calculation of terrain clearance and lowest usable flight level: The aircraft must fly at 8 240 ft (6 240 ft + 2 000 ft)
This altitude must be the true altitude of the aircraft

This altitude must be corrected for any temperature ISA deviation and then any difference in pressure from standard (1013 hPa), to get the pressure altitude, allowing us to work out the lowest usable flight level
learning.explanation: Calculation of terrain clearance and lowest usable flight level: The aircraft must fly at 8 240 ft (6 240 ft + 2 000 ft). This altitude must be the true altitude of the aircraft. This altitude must be corrected for any temperature ISA deviation and then any difference in pressure from standard (1013 hPa), to get the pressure altitude, allowing us to work out the lowest usable flight level. The first step is to determine the temperature correction. The ISA deviation is ISA -12ºC. For the temperature correction, the airfield elevation must be taken into account: 8 240 ft - 1 240 ft = 7 000 ft. Based on the 4% rule and its calculation mentioned in the rules below, the height correction for the temperature can be calculated as follows: Height correction for temperature = 4 × (-12) × (7 000/1000) = -336 ft. In this case, the temperature correction is added to the true altitude as per the rules below (refer to the table below), to give an indicated altitude of ­­8 576 ft. Next, we need to compute the pressure correction by considering the deviation from the standard mean sea level pressure of 1013 hPa: 1013 hPa - 1000 hPa = 13 hPa. Since the barometric lapse rate near the surface is 30 ft/hPa, the pressure correction can be calculated as follows: Pressure correction = 13 hPa x 30 ft/hPa = 390 ft. This value needs to be added to the indicated altitude as per the rules below: Pressure Altitude = 8 576 ft + 390 ft = 8 966 ft. Thus, the Minimum Flight Level, which provides obstacle clearance, after both pressure and temperature correction, that must be selected is: FL90. RULES. The following rules should be considered for altimetry calculations: All calculations are based on rounded pressure values to the nearest lower hPa. The value for the barometric lapse rate between MSL and 500 hPa to be used is 30 ft/hPa as an acceptable approximation of the barometric lapse rate. To determine the true altitude/height, the following rule of thumb, called the ‘4 %-rule’, shall be used: the altitude/height changes by 4% for each 10°C temperature deviation from ISA. For simplification: Height correction for the temp = 4 × (ISA DEV) × Indicated alt/1000 = ___ ft If no further information is given, the deviation of the outside-air temperature from ISA is considered to be the same throughout the whole layer. The elevation of the aerodrome has to be taken into account. The temperature correction has to be considered for the layer between the station (usually an aerodrome) and the position of the aircraft. HIGHER PRESSURE; INDICATED ALTITUDE > PRESSURE ALTITUDE LOWER PRESSURE; INDICATED ALTITUDE < PRESSURE ALTITUDE WARMER THAN ISA; TRUE ALTITUDE > INDICATED ALTITUDE COLDER THAN ISA; TRUE ALTITUDE < INDICATED ALTITUDE DEFINITIONS. Pressure Altitude: The altimeter indication with standard pressure (1013.2 hPa) set. Indicated Altitude: The altimeter indication with local QNH set. True altitude: The actual altitude of the aircraft above mean sea level.

content.question: A VFR flight is planned from aerodrome A to aerodrome B on a 085° track. What would be an appropriate Flight Level for this route?

key_points: In order to apply vertical separation, the ICAO VFR Semi-Circular Rule must be followed
The ICAO VFR semi-circular rule can be derived, which permits the selection of FLs, in accordance with aircraft’s magnetic track
Tracks are specified as being either ‘eastbound’ or ‘westbound’
learning.explanation: In order to apply vertical separation, the ICAO VFR Semi-Circular Rule must be followed. The ICAO VFR semi-circular rule can be derived, which permits the selection of FLs, in accordance with aircraft’s magnetic track. Tracks are specified as being either ‘eastbound’ or ‘westbound’. Eastbound tracks are 000°M - 179°M inclusive, and westbound, 180°M - 359°M inclusive. For the eastbound magnetic tracks we select Odd Fls + 500 ft (35,55,75, etc.). For the westbound magnetic tracks we select Even FLs + 500 ft (25,45,65, etc.). The question does not specify if the track is magnetic or true, but whichever the variation could be, the track still remains eastbound. Therefore, according to the ICAO VFR semi-circular rule, the FL that must be selected for 085° track is FL55.

For an aircraft flying VFR from Straubing (EDMS) aerodrome (N48°54.0’ E012°31.1’) to Linz international (LOWL) aerodrome (N48°14.1’ E014°11.3’), what is the best cruising altitude according to ICAO semi-circular rule, VFR checkpoint and ground navigational aid to tune to?

key_points: Firstly, find the exact position of the two aerodromes, using the coordinates given, draw a straight line as a route between them and examine each statement carefully

learning.explanation: Firstly, find the exact position of the two aerodromes, using the coordinates given, draw a straight line as a route between them and examine each statement carefully. Altitude selection: Before the route is recorded on the flight plan, we need to consider the altitude to fly at. The Minimum Grid Area Altitudes along the route are 5 400 ft, 7 200 ft and 4 100 ft. For this VFR flight, the minimum safe altitude along the whole route is 7 200 ft. But, we have to also consider the ICAO VFR cruising altitudes and select an appropriate altitude for this easterly magnetic track. According to the ICAO VFR semi-circular rule, for an easterly magnetic track, Odd FLs/Altitudes + 500 ft must be followed (3 500 ft, 5 500 ft, 7 500 ft, etc.). So, a cruise altitude of 7 500 ft can be followed, which apart from being according to the ICAO rule, it provides enough obstacle clearance too. In portions of the whole route, a lower altitude could be flown, 5 500 ft, but with less vertical obstacle clearance provided, probably poor comms signal and encountered turbulence. Ground feature selection: Line features, such as highways, which cross vertically the intended track are highly recommended as ground features for navigation in VFR flights. Both Highways, A3 and A92, as line features, are very helpful for groundspeed and timing checks, because they both cross vertically the track. But among them, the A3 highway is more preferred since it is almost halfway. Of course, the Power plant at Vilshofen (1 593 ft) could be selected as a VFR checkpoint, since it covers the criteria that should be considered for a VFR ground feature selection, but the question asks for the best. NavAid selection: Between the LNZ and FRE VOR/DME, the former is the best to tune to, even just after take-off (if both relief and VOR’s range permit), since it easily leads to the destination, almost directly, with an insignificant course deviation.

content.question: You want to plan a VFR flight within a controlled airspace using your GNSS flight plan as a back-up navigation method. Which of the following are best suited as significant points for entering into your GNSS flight plan as VFR waypoints using a distance and bearing?

key_points: The question is poorly worded as none of the answers in this question fit the criteria for visual fix points that can be defined by a distance and bearing from a known point, nor are they suitable as known points for creating a distance and bearing to a VFR waypoint
The only possible known point for defining a VFR waypoint via bearing and distance is the airport reference point (ARP)
An airport reference point (ARP) is a known and well-defined location on an airport used as a reference for navigation purposes
learning.explanation: The question is poorly worded as none of the answers in this question fit the criteria for visual fix points that can be defined by a distance and bearing from a known point, nor are they suitable as known points for creating a distance and bearing to a VFR waypoint. The only possible known point for defining a VFR waypoint via bearing and distance is the airport reference point (ARP). An airport reference point (ARP) is a known and well-defined location on an airport used as a reference for navigation purposes. Using the ARP as a waypoint in a GNSS flight plan provides a reliable and accurate navigation aid for VFR flights, especially when flying within controlled airspace. This is because the ARP is precisely located on aviation charts and is well-known to air traffic controllers, making it easier to communicate your position to ATC if necessary. Power lines, major cities and large towns, and coastlines may be visually identifiable landmarks that can assist with navigation, but they are not as precise and reliable as using an airport reference point. Additionally, power lines may not always be visible, and coastlines can be affected by changing weather conditions, tides, and other factors, making them less reliable as navigation aids. Major cities and large towns can be useful as general orientation points but may not provide the necessary precision needed for accurate navigation within a controlled airspace.

How many feet you have to climb to reach FL75? Given:

QNH = 1023 hPa
Temperature = ISA

key_points: One of the methods used to solve this question is to calculate True Altitude based on the provided Pressure Altitude - by correcting it for QNH deviation and for Temperature deviation
Note that in this case, temperature = ISA, therefore we can disregard the latter
Adjust for QNH deviation If QNH is higher than 1013 hPa => Indicated Altitude is lower than True Altitude
learning.explanation: One of the methods used to solve this question is to calculate True Altitude based on the provided Pressure Altitude - by correcting it for QNH deviation and for Temperature deviation. Note that in this case, temperature = ISA, therefore we can disregard the latter. Adjust for QNH deviation If QNH is higher than 1013 hPa => Indicated Altitude is lower than True Altitude. If QNH is lower than 1013 hPa => Indicated Altitude is higher than True Altitude. 1023 – 1013 = 10 hPa 10 hPa x 30 ft = 300 ft With regards to this question, QNH is 10 hPa higher than standard, therefore, True altitude is 30 hPa higher than IA => 7500 ft + 300 ft = 7 800 ft. When you climb from the airport with an elevation of 1 500 ft to True Altitude of 7 800 ft, you will climb 7800 - 1500 = 6300 ft.

Large built-up areas do not constitute good pinpoints. Also, small towns and villages all look almost the same from the air. Small built-up areas are recommended, when they are isolated and close to obvious ground features, such as lakes, reservoirs, junctions and nearby to identify it. In the vicinity of Albstadt Degerfeld aerodrome (EDSA) there are many elevation spots, villages and T junctions of secondary roads east off EDSA airfield, so you have to find something as unique as possible. The only well-distinguished and unique ground feature for a pilot flying VFR in the vicinity of Albstadt Degerfield aerodrome is the railway T-junction near GAMMERTINGEN village (N48o 15’, E009o 13’), because it is a combination of an isolated small built-up area with an obvious line feature.
